speech.line: I hope in no place ſo vnſanƈtified,
Where ſuch as thou may’ſt finde him.

speech.speaker: Mur.
speech.line: He’s a Traitor.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Thou ly’ſt thou ſhagge-ear’d Villaine.

speech.speaker: Mur.
speech.line: What you Egge?
Yong fry of Treachery?

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: He ha’s kill’d me Mother,
Run away I pray you.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Let vs ſeeke out ſome deſolate ſhade, & there
Weepe our ſad boſomes empty.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Let vs rather
Hold faſt the mortall Sword: and like good men,
Beſtride our downfall Birthdome: each new Morne,
New Widdowes howle, new Orphans cry, new ſorowes
Strike heauen on the face, that it reſounds
As if it felt with Scotland, and yell’d out
Like Syllable of Dolour.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: What I beleeue, Ile waile;
What know, beleeue; and what I can redreſſe,
As I ſhall finde the time to friend: I wil.
What you haue ſpoke, it may be ſo perchance.
This Tyrant, whoſe ſole name bliſters our tongues,
Was once thought honeſt: you haue lou’d him well,
He hath not touch’d you yet. I am yong, but ſomething
You may diſcerne of him through me, and wiſedome
To offer vp a weake, poore innocent Lambe
T’appeaſe an angry God.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: I am not treacherous.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: But Macbeth is.
A good and vertuous Nature may recoyle
In an Imperiall charge. But I ſhall craue your pardon:
That which you are, my thoughts cannot tranſpoſe;
Angels are bright ſtill, though the brighteſt fell.
Though all things foule, would wear the brows of grace
Yet Grace muſt ſtill looke ſo.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: I haue loſt my Hopes.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Perchance euen there
Where I did finde my doubts.
Why in that rawneſſe left you Wife, and Childe?
Thoſe precious Motiues, thoſe ſtrong knots of Loue,
Without leaue-taking. I pray you,
Let not my Iealouſies, be your Diſhonors,
But mine owne Safeties: you may be rightly iuſt,
What euer I ſhall thinke.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Bleed, bleed poore Country,
Great Tyrrany, lay thou thy baſis ſure,
For goodneſſe dare not check thee: wear ÿ thy wrongs,
The Title, is affear’d. Far thee well Lord,
I would not be the Villaine that thou think’ſt,
For the whole Space that’s in the Tyrants Graſpe,
And the rich Eaſt to boot.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Be not offended:
I ſpeake not as in abſolute feare of you:
I thinke our Country ſinkes beneath the yoake,
It weepes, it bleeds, and each new day a gaſh
Is added to her wounds. I thinke withall,
There would be hands vplifted in my right:
And heere from gracious England haue I offer
Of goodly thouſands. But for all this,
When I ſhall treade vpon the Tyrants head,
Or weare it on my Sword; yet my poore Country
Shall haue more vices then it had before,
More ſuffer, and more ſundry wayes then euer,
By him that ſhall ſucceede.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: What ſhould he be?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: It is my ſelfe I meane: in whom I know
All the particulars of Vice ſo grafted,
That when they ſhall be open’d, blacke Macbeth
Will ſeeme as pure as Snow, and the poore State
Eſteeme him as a Lambe, being compar’d
With my confineleſſe harmes.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Not in the Legions
Of horrid Hell, can come a Diuell more damn’d
In euils, to top Macbeth.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I grant him Bloody,
Luxurious, Auaricious, Falſe, Deceitfull,
Sodaine, Malicious, ſmacking of euery ſinne
That ha’s a name. But there’s no bottome, none
In my Voluptuouſneſſe: Your Wiues, your Daughters,
Your Matrons, and your Maides, could not fill vp
The Ceſterne of my Luſt, and my Deſire
All continent Impediments would ore-beare
That did oppoſe my will. Better Macbeth,
Then ſuch an one to reigne.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Boundleſſe intemperance
In Nature is a Tyranny: It hath beene
Th’ vntimely emptying of the happy Throne,
And fall of many Kings. But feare not yet
To take vpon you what is yours: you may
Conuey your pleaſures in a ſpacious plenty,
And yet ſeeme cold. The time you may ſo hoodwinke:
We haue willing Dames enough: there cannot be
That Vulture in you, to deuoure ſo many
As will to Greatneſſe dedicate themſelues,
Finding it ſo inclinde.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: With this, there growes
In my moſt ill-compos’d Affeƈtion, ſuch
A ſtanchleſſe Auarice, that were I King,
I ſhould cut off the Nobles for their Lands,
Deſire his Iewels, and this others Houſe,
And my more-hauing, would be as a Sawce
To make me hunger more, that I ſhould forge
Quarrels vniuſt againſt the Good and Loyall,
Deſtroying them for wealth.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: This Auarice
ſtickes deeper: growes with more pernicious roote
Then Summer-ſeeming Luſt: and it hath bin
The Sword of our ſlaine Kings: yet do not feare,
Scotland hath Foyſons, to fill vp your will
Of your meere Owne. All theſe are portable,
With other Graces weigh’d.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: But I haue none. The King-becoming Graces,
As Iustice, Verity, Temp’rance, Stableneſſe,
Bounty, Perſeuerance, Mercy, Lowlineſſe,
Deuotion, Patience, Courage, Fortitude,
I haue no relliſh of them, but abound
In the diuiſion of each ſeuerall Crime,
Aƈting it many wayes. Nay, had I powre, I ſhould
Poure the ſweet Milke of Concord, into Hell,
Vprore the vniuerſall peace, confound
All vnity on earth.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: O Scotland, Scotland.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: If ſuch a one be fit to gouerne, ſpeake:
I am as I haue ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Mac.
speech.line: Fit to gouern? No not to liue. O Natiō miſerable!
With an vntitled Tyrant, bloody Sceptred,
When ſhalt thou ſee thy wholſome dayes againe?
Since that the trueſt Iſſue of thy Throne
By his owne Interdiƈtion ſtands accuſt,
And do’s blaſpheme his breed? Thy Royall Father
Was a moſt Sainted-King: the Queene that bore thee,
Oftner vpon her knees, then on her feet,
Dy’de euery day ſhe liu’d. Fare thee well,
Theſe Euils thou repeat’ſt vpon thy ſelfe,
Hath baniſh’d me from Scotland. O my Breſt,
Thy hope ends heere.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Macduff, this Noble paſſion
Childe of integrity, hath from my ſoule
Wip’d the blacke Scruples, reconcil’d my thoughts
To thy good Truth, and Honor. Diuelliſh Macbeth,
By many of these traines, hath ſought to win me
Into his power: and modeſt Wiſedome pluckes me
From ouer-credulous haſt: but God aboue
Deale betweene thee and me; For euen now
I put my ſelfe to thy Direƈtion, and
Vnſpeake mine owne detraƈtion. Heere abiure
The taints, and blames I laide vpon my ſelfe,
For ſtrangers to my Nature. I am yet
Vnknowne to Woman, neuer was forſworne,
Scarſely haue coueted what was mine owne.
At no time broke my Faith, would not betray
The Deuill to his Fellow, and delight
No leſſe in truth then life. My firſt falſe ſpeaking
Was this vpon my ſelfe. What I am truly
Is thine, and my poore Countries to command:
Whither indeed, before they heere approach
Old Seyward with ten thouſand warlike men
Already at a point, was ſetting foorth:
Now wee’l together, and the chance of goodneſſe
Be like our warranted Quarrell. Why are you ſilent?

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Such welcome, and vnwelcom things at once
’Tis hard to reconcile.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Well, more anon. Comes the King forth
I pray you?

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: I Sir: there are a crew of wretched Soules
That ſtay his Cure: their malady conuinces
The great aſſay of Art. But at his touch,
Such ſanƈtity hath Heauen giuen his hand,
They preſently amend.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I thanke you Doƈtor.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: What’s the Diſeaſe he meanes?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Tis call’d the Euill.
A moſt myraculous worke in this good King,
Which often ſince my heere remaine in England,
I haue ſeene him do: How he ſolicites heauen
Himſelfe beſt knowes: but ſtrangely viſited people
All ſwolne and Vlcerous, pittifull to the eye,
The meere diſpaire of Surgery, he cures,
Hanging a golden ſtampe about their neckes,
Put on with holy Prayers, and ’tis ſpoken
To the ſucceeding Royalty he leaues
The healing Benediƈtion. With this ſtrange vertue,
He hath a heauenly guift of Propheſie,
And ſundry Bleſſings hang about his Throne,
That ſpeake him full of Grace.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: See who comes heere.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: My Countryman: but yet I know him not.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: My euer gentle Cozen, welcome hither.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: I know him now. Good God betimes remoue
The meanes that makes vs Strangers.

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Sir, Amen.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Stands Scotland where it did?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Alas poore Countrey,
Almoſt affraid to know it ſelfe. It cannot
Be call’d our Mother, but our Graue; where nothing
But who knowes nothing, is once ſeene to ſmile:
Where ſighes, and groanes, and ſhrieks that rent the ayre
Are made, not mark’d: Where violent ſorrow ſeemes
A Moderne extaſie: The Deadmans knell,
Is there ſcarſe ask’d for who, and good mens liues
Expire before the Flowers in their Caps,
Dying, or ere they ſicken.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Oh Relation; too nice, and yet too true.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: What’s the newest griefe?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: That of an houres age, doth hiſſe the ſpeaker,
Each minute teemes a new one.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: How do’s my Wife?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Why well.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: And all my Children?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Well too.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: The Tyrant ha’s not batter’d at their peace?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: No, they were wel at peace, when I did leaue ’em

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Be not a niggard of your ſpeech: How gos’t?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: When I came hither to tranſport the Tydings
Which I haue heauily borne, there ran a Rumour
Of many worthy Fellowes, that were out,
Which was to my beleefe witneſt the rather,
For that I ſaw the Tyrants Power a-foot.
Now is the time of helpe: your eye in Scotland
Would create Soldiours, make our women fight,
To doffe their dire diſtreſſes.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Bee’t their comfort
We are comming thither: Gracious England hath
Lent vs good Seyward, and ten thouſand men,
An older, and a better Souldier, none
That Chriſtendome giues out.

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Would I could anſwer
This comfort with the like. But I haue words
That would be howl’d out in the deſert ayre,
Where hearing ſhould not latch them.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: What concerne they,
The generall cauſe, or is it a Fee-griefe
Due to ſome ſingle breſt?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: No minde that’s honeſt
But in it ſhares ſome woe, though the maine part
Pertaines to you alone.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: If it be mine
Keepe it not from me, quickly let me haue it.

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Let not your eares diſpiſe my tongue for euer,
Which ſhall poſſeſſe them with the heauieſt ſound
That euer yet they heard.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Humh: I gueſſe at it.

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Your Caſtle is ſurpriz’d: your Wife, and Babes
Sauagely ſlaughter’d: To relate the manner
Were on the Quarry of theſe murther’d Deere
To adde the death of you.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Mercifull Heauen:
What man, ne’re pull your hat vpon your browes:
Giue ſorrow words; the griefe that do’s not ſpeake,
Whiſpers the o’re-fraught heart, and bids it breake.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: My Children too?

speech.speaker: Ro.
speech.line: Wife, Children, Seruants, all that could be found.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: And I muſt be from thence? My wife kil’d too?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: I haue ſaid.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Be comforted.
Let’s make vs Med’cines of our great Reuenge,
To cure this deadly greefe.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: He ha’s no Children. All my pretty ones?
Did you ſay All? Oh Hell-Kite! All?
What, All my pretty Chickens, and their Damme
At one fell ſwoope?

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Diſpute it like a man.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: I ſhall do ſo:
But I must also feele it as a man;
I cannot but remember ſuch things were
That were moſt precious to me: Did heauen looke on,
And would not take their part? Sinfull Macduff,
They were all ſtrooke for thee: Naught that I am,
Not for their owne demerits, but for mine
Fell ſlaughter on their ſoules: Heauen reſt them now.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Be this the Whetſtone of your ſword, let griefe
Conuert to anger: blunt not the heart, enrage it.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: O I could play the woman with mine eyes,
And Braggart with my tongue. But gentle Heauens,
Cut ſhort all intermiſſion: Front to Front,
Bring thou this Fiend of Scotland, and my ſelfe
Within my Swords length ſet him, if he ſcape
Heauen forgiue him too.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: This time goes manly:
Come go we to the King, our Power is ready,
Our lacke is nothing but our leaue. Macbeth
Is ripe for ſhaking, and the Powres aboue
Put on their Inſtruments: Receiue what cheere you may,
The Night is long, that neuer findes the Day.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Doƈtor of Phyſicke, and a Wayting Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: I haue too Nights watch’d with you, but can
perceiue no truth in your report. When was it ſhee laſt
walk’d?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Since his Maieſty went into the Field, I haue
ſeene her riſe from her bed, throw her Night-Gown vp-
pon her, vnlocke her Cloſſet, take foorth paper, folde it,
write vpon’t, read it, afterwards Seale it, and againe re-
turne to bed; yet all this while in a moſt faſt ſleepe.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: A great perturbation in Nature, to receyue at
once the benefit of ſleep, and do the effeƈts of watching.
In this ſlumbry agitation, beſides her walking, and other
aƈtuall performances, what (at any time) haue you heard
her ſay?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: That Sir, which I will not report after her.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: You may to me, and ’tis moſt meet you ſhould.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Neither to you, nor any one, hauing no witneſſe
to confirme my ſpeech.
Lo you, heere ſhe comes: This is her very guiſe, and vp-
on my life faſt aſleepe: obſerue her, ſtand cloſe.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: How came ſhe by that light?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Why it ſtood by her: ſhe ha’s light by her con-
tinually, ’tis her command.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: You ſee her eyes are open.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I, but their ſenſe are ſhut.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: What is it ſhe do’s now?
Looke how ſhe rubbes her hands.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: It is an accuſtom’d aƈtion with her, to ſeeme
thus waſhing her hands: I haue knowne her continue in
this a quarter of an houre.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: Yet heere’s a ſpot.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Heark, ſhe ſpeaks, I will ſet downe what comes
from her, to ſatiſfie my remembrance the more ſtrongly.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Out damned ſpot: out I ſay. One: Two: Why
then ’tis time to doo’t: Hell is murky. Fye, my Lord, fie,
a Souldier, and affear’d? what need we feare? who knowes
it, when none can call our powre to accompt: yet who
would haue thought the olde man to haue had ſo much
blood in him.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Do you marke that?

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: The Thane of Fife, had a wife: where is ſhe now?
What will theſe hands ne’re be cleane? No more o’that
my Lord, no more oſthat: you marre all with this ſtar-
ting.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Go too, go too:
You haue knowne what you ſhould not.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: She ha’s ſpoke what ſhee ſhould not, I am ſure
of that: Heauen knowes what ſhe ha’s knowne.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Heere’s the ſmell of the blood ſtill: all the per-
fumes of Arabia will not ſweeten this little hand.
Oh, oh, oh.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: What a ſigh is there? The hart is ſorely charg’d.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I would not haue ſuch a heart in my boſome,
for the dignity of the whole body.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Well, well, well.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Pray God it be ſir.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: This diſeaſe is beyond my praƈtiſe: yet I haue
knowne thoſe which haue walkt in their ſleep, who haue
dyed holily in their beds.

speech.speaker: Lad.
speech.line: Waſh your hands, put on your Night-Gowne,
looke not ſo pale: I tell you yet againe Banquo’s buried;
he cannot come out on’s graue.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Euen ſo?

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: To bed, to bed: there’s knocking at the gate:
Come, come, come, come, giue me your hand: What’s
done, cannot be vndone. To bed, to bed, to bed.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Will ſhe go now to bed?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Direƈtly.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Foule whiſp’rings are abroad: vnnaturall deeds
Do breed vnnaturall troubles: infeƈted mindes
To their deafe pillowes will diſcharge their Secrets:
More needs ſhe the Diuine, then the Phyſitian:
God, God forgiue vs all. Looke after her,
Remoue from her the meanes of all annoyance,
And ſtill keepe eyes vpon her: So goodnight,
My minde ſhe ha’s mated, and amaz’d my ſight.
I thinke, but dare not ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Good night good Doƈtor.

scene.stagedir: Drum and Colours. Enter Menteth, Cathnes, Angus, Lenox, Soldiers.

speech.speaker: Ment.
speech.line: The Engliſh powre is neere, led on by Malcolm,
His Vnkle Seyward, and the good Macduff.
Reuenges burne in them: for their deere cauſes
Would to the bleeding, and the grim Alarme
Excite the mortified man.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Neere Byrnan wood
Shall we well meet them, that way are they comming.

speech.speaker: Cath.
speech.line: Who knowes if Donalbane be with his brother?

speech.speaker: Len.
speech.line: For certaine Sir, he is not: I haue a File
Of all the Gentry; there is Seywards Sonne,
And many vnruffe youths, that euen now
Proteſt their firſt of Manhood.

speech.speaker: Ment.
speech.line: What do’s the Tyrant.

speech.speaker: Cath.
speech.line: Great Dunſinane he ſtrongly Fortifies:
Some ſay hee’s mad: Others, that leſſer hate him,
Do call it valiant Fury, but for certaine
He cannot buckle his diſtemper’d cauſe
Within the belt of Rule.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Now do’s he feele
His ſecret Murthers ſticking on his hands,
Now minutely Reuolts vpbraid his Faith-breach:
Thoſe he commands, moue onely in command,
Nothing in loue: Now do’s he feele his Title
Hang looſe about him, like a Giants Robe
Vpon a dwarfiſh Theefe.

speech.speaker: Ment.
speech.line: Who then ſhall blame
His peſter’d Senſes to recoyle, and ſtart,
When all that is within him, do’s condemne
It ſelfe, for being there.

speech.speaker: Cath.
speech.line: Well, march we on,
To giue Obedience, where ’tis truly ow’d:
Meet we the Med’cine of the ſickly Weale,
And with him poure we in our Countries purge,
Each drop of vs.

speech.speaker: Lenox.
speech.line: Or ſo much as it needes,
To dew the Soueraigne Flower, and drowne the Weeds:
Make we our March towards Birnan.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Bring me no more Reports, let them flye all:
Till Byrnane wood remoue to Dunſinane,
I cannot taint with Feare. What’s the Boy Malcolme?
Was he not borne of woman? The Spirits that know
All mortall Conſequences, haue pronounc’d me thus:
Feare not Macbeth, no man that’s borne of woman
Shall ere haue power vpon thee. Then fly falſe Thanes,
And mingle with the Engliſh Epicures,
The minde I ſway by, and the heart I beare,
Shall neuer ſagge with doubt, nor ſhake with feare.
The diuell damne thee blacke, thou cream-fac’d Loone:
Where got’ſt thou that Gooſe-looke.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: There is ten thouſand.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Geeſe Villaine?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Souldiers Sir.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Go pricke thy face, and ouer-red thy feare
Thou Lilly-liuer’d Boy. What Soldiers, Patch?
Death of thy Soule, thoſe Linnen cheekes of thine
Are Counſailers to feare. What Soldiers Whay-face?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: The Engliſh Force, ſo pleaſe you.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Take thy face hence. Seyton, I am ſick at hart,
When I behold: Seyton, I ſay, this puſh
Will cheere me euer, or diſ-eate me now.
I haue liu’d long enough: my way of life
Is falne into the Seare, the yellow Leafe,
And that which ſhould accompany Old-Age,
As Honor, Loue, Obedience, Troopes of Friends,
I muſt not looke to haue: but in their ſteed,
Curſes, not lowd but deepe, Mouth-honor, breath
Which the poore heart would faine deny, and dare not.
Seyton?

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: What’s your gracious pleaſure?

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: What Newes more?

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: All is confirm’d my Lord, which was reported.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Ile fight, till from my bones, my fleſh be hackt.
Giue me my Armor.

speech.speaker: Seyt.
speech.line: ’Tis not needed yet.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Ile put it on:
Send out moe Horſes, ſkirre the Country round,
Hang thoſe that talke of Feare. Giue me mine Armor:
How do’s your Patient, Doƈtor?

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Not ſo ſicke my Lord,
As ſhe is troubled with thicke-comming Fancies
That keepe her from her reſt.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Cure of that:
Can’ſt thou not Miniſter to a minde diſeas’d,
Plucke from the Memory a rooted Sorrow,
Raze out the written troubles of the Braine,
And with ſome ſweet Obliuious Antidote
Cleanſe the ſtufft boſome, of that perillous ſtuffe
Which weighes vpon the heart?

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Therein the Patient
Muſt miniſter to himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Throw Phyſicke to the Dogs, Ile none of it.
Come, put mine Armour on: giue me my Staffe:
Seyton, ſend out: Doƈtor, the Thanes flye from me:
Come ſir, diſpatch. If thou could’ſt Doƈtor, caſt
The Water of my Land, finde her Diſeaſe,
And purge it to a ſound and priſtine Health,
I would applaud thee to the very Eccho,
That ſhould applaud againe. Pull’t off I ſay,
What Rubarb, Cyme, or what Purgatiue drugge
Would ſcowre theſe Engliſh hence: hear’ſt ȳ of them?

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: I my good Lord: your Royall Preparation
Makes vs heare ſomething.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Bring it after me:
I will not be affraid of Death and Bane,
Till Birnane Forreſt come to Dunſinane.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Were I from Dunſinane away, and cleere,
Profit againe ſhould hardly draw me heere.

scene.stagedir: Drum and Colours. Enter Malcolme, Seyward, Macduffe, Seywards Sonne, Menteth, Cathnes, Angus, and Soldiers Marching.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Coſins, I hope the dayes are neere at hand
That Chambers will be ſafe.

speech.speaker: Ment.
speech.line: We doubt it nothing.

speech.speaker: Seyw.
speech.line: What wood is this before vs?

speech.speaker: Ment.
speech.line: The wood of Birnane.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: Let euery Souldier hew him downe a Bough,
And bear’t before him, thereby ſhall we ſhadow
The numbers of our Hoaſt, and make diſcouery
Erre in report of vs.

speech.speaker: Sold.
speech.line: It ſhall be done.

speech.speaker: Syw.
speech.line: We learne no other, but the confident Tyrant
Keepes ſtill in Dunſinane, and will indure
Our ſetting downe befor’t.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: ’Tis his maine hope:
For where there is aduantage to be giuen,
Both more and leſſe haue giuen him the Reuolt,
And none ſerue with him, but conſtrained things,
Whoſe hearts are abſent too.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Let our iuſt Cenſures
Attend the true euent, and put we on
Induſtrious Souldierſhip.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: The time approaches,
That will with due deciſion make vs know
What we ſhall ſay we haue, and what we owe:
Thoughts ſpeculatiue, their vnſure hopes relate,
But certaine iſſue, ſtroakes muſt arbitrate,
Towards which, aduance the warre.

scene.stagedir: Enter Macbeth, Seyton, & Souldiers, with Drum and Colours.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Hang out our Banners on the outward walls,
The Cry is ſtill, they come: our Caſtles ſtrength
Will laugh a Siedge to ſcorne: Heere let them lye,
Till Famine and the Ague eate them vp:
Were they not forc’d with thoſe that ſhould be ours,
We might haue met them darefull, beard to beard,
And beate them backward home. What is that noyſe?

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: It is the cry of women, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: I haue almoſt forgot the taſte of Feares:
The time ha’s beene, my ſences would haue cool’d
To heare a Night-ſhrieke, and my Fell of haire
Would at a diſmall Treatiſe rowze, and ſtirre
As life were in’t. I haue ſupt full with horrors,
Direneſſe familiar to my ſlaughterous thoughts
Cannot once ſtart me. Wherefore was that cry?

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: The Queene (my Lord) is dead.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: She ſhould haue dy’de heereafter;
There would haue beene a time for ſuch a word:
To morrow, and to morrow, and to morrow,
Creepes in this petty pace from day to day,
To the laſt Syllable of Recorded time:
And all our yeſterdayes, haue lighted Fooles
The way to duſty death. Out, out, breefe Candle,
Life’s but a walking Shadow, a poore Player,
That ſtruts and frets his houre vpon the Stage,
And then is heard no more. It is a Tale
Told by an Ideot, full of ſound and fury
Signifying nothing.
Thou com’ſt to vſe thy Tongue: thy Story quickly.

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: Gracious my Lord,
I ſhould report that which I ſay I ſaw,
But know not how to doo’t.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Well, ſay ſir.

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: As I did ſtand my watch vpon the Hill
I look’d toward Byrnane, and anon me thought
The Wood began to moue.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Lyar, and Slaue.

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: Let me endure your wrath, if’t be not ſo:
Within this three Mile may you ſee it comming.
I ſay, a mouing Groue.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: If thou ſpeak’ſt falſe,
Vpon the next Tree ſhall thou hang aliue
Till Famine cling thee: If thy ſpeech be ſooth,
I care not if thou doſt for me as much.
I pull in Reſolution, and begin
To doubt th’ Equiuocation of the Fiend,
That lies like truth. Feare not, till Byrnane Wood
Do come to Dunſinane, and now a Wood
Comes toward Dunſinane. Arme, Arme, and out,
If this which he auouches, do’s appeare,
There is nor flying hence, nor tarrying here.
I ’ginne to be a-weary of the Sun,
And wiſh th’ eſtate o’th’ world were now vndon.
Ring the Alarum Bell, blow Winde, come wracke,
At leaſt wee’l dye with Harneſſe on our backe.

scene.stagedir: Drumme and Colours. Enter Malcolme, Seyward, Macduffe, and their Army, with Boughes.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Now neere enough:
Your leauy Skreenes throw downe,
And ſhew like thoſe you are: You (worthy Vnkle)
Shall with my Coſin your right Noble Sonne
Leade our firſt Battell. Worthy Macduffe, and wee
Shall take vpon’s what elſe remaines to do,
According to our order.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: Fare you well:
Do we but finde the Tyrants power to night,
Let vs be beaten, if we cannot fight.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Make all our Trumpets ſpeak, giue thē all breath
Thoſe clamorous Harbingers of Blood, & Death.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: They haue tied me to a ſtake, I cannot flye,
But Beare-like I must fight the courſe. What’s he
That was not borne of Woman? Such a one
Am I to feare, or none.

speech.speaker: Y. Sey.
speech.line: What is thy name?

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Thou’lt be affraid to heare it.

speech.speaker: Y. Sey.
speech.line: No: though thou call’ſt thy ſelfe a hoter name
Then any is in hell.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: My name’s Macbeth.

speech.speaker: Y. Sey.
speech.line: The diuell himſelfe could not pronounce a Title
More hatefull to mine eare.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: No: nor more fearefull.

speech.speaker: Y. Sey.
speech.line: Thou lyeſt abhorred Tyrant, with my Sword
Ile proue the lye thou ſpeak’ſt.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Thou was’t borne of woman;
But Swords I ſmile at, Weapons laugh to ſcorne,
Brandiſh’d by man that’s of a Woman borne.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: That way the noiſe is: Tyrant ſhew thy face,
If thou beeſt ſlaine, and with no ſtroake of mine,
My Wife and Childrens Ghoſts will haunt me ſtill:
I cannot ſtrike at wretched Kernes, whoſe armes
Are hyr’d to beare their Staues; either thou Macbeth,
Or elſe my Sword with an vnbattered edge
I ſheath againe vndeeded. There thou ſhould’ſt be,
By this great clatter, one of greateſt note
Seemes bruited. Let me finde him Fortune,
And more I begge not.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: This way my Lord, the Caſtles gently rendred:
The Tyrants people, on both ſides do fight,
The Noble Thanes do brauely in the Warre,
The day almoſt it ſelfe profeſſes yours,
And little is to do.

speech.speaker: Malc.
speech.line: We haue met with Foes
That ſtrike beſide vs.

speech.speaker: Sey
speech.line: Enter Sir, the Caſtle.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Why ſhould I play the Roman Foole, and dye
On mine owne ſword? whiles I ſee liues, the gaſhes
Do better vpon them.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Turne Hell-hound, turne.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Of all men elſe I haue auoyded thee:
But get thee backe, my ſoule is too much charg’d
With blood of thine already.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: I haue no words,
My voice is in my Sword, thou bloodier Villaine
Then tearmes can giue thee out.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Thou looſeſt labour
As eaſie may’ſt thou the intrenchant Ayre
With thy keene Sword impreſſe, as make me bleed:
Let fall thy blade on vulnerable Creſts,
I beare a charmed Life, which muſt not yeeld
To one of woman borne.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Diſpaire thy Charme,
And let the Angell whom thou ſtill haſt ſeru’d
Tell thee, Macduffe was from his Mothers womb
Vntimely ript.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: Accurſed be that tongue that tels mee ſo;
For it hath Cow’d my better part of man:
And be theſe Iugling Fiends no more beleeu’d,
That palter with vs in a double ſence,
That keepe the word of promiſe to our eare,
And breake it to our hope. Ile not fight with thee.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Then yeeld thee Coward,
And liue to be the ſhew, and gaze o’th’ time.
Wee’l haue thee, as our rarer Monſters are
Painted vpon a pole, and vnder-writ,
Heere may you ſee the Tyrant.

speech.speaker: Macb.
speech.line: I will not yeeld
To kiſſe the ground before young Malcolmes feet,
And to be baited with the Rabbles curſe.
Though Byrnane wood be come to Dunſinane,
And thou oppos’d, being of no woman borne,
Yet I will try the laſt. Before my body,
I throw my warlike Shield: Lay on Macduffe,
And damn’d be him, that firſt cries hold, enough.

scene.stagedir: Retreat, and Flouriſh. Enter with Drumme and Colours, Malcolm, Seyward, Roſſe, Thanes, & Soldiers.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I would the Friends we miſſe, were ſafe arriu’d.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: Some muſt go off: and yet by theſe I ſee,
So great a day as this is cheapely bought.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Macduffe is miſſing, and your Noble Sonne.

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: Your ſon my Lord, ha’s paid a ſouldiers debt,
He onely liu’d but till he was a man,
The which no ſooner had his Proweſſe confirm’d
In the vnſhrinking ſtation where he fought,
But like a man he dy’de.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: Then he is dead?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: I, and brought off the field: your cauſe of ſorrow
Muſt not be measur’d by his worth, for then
It hath no end.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: Had he his hurts before?

speech.speaker: Roſſe.
speech.line: I, on the Front.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: Why then, Gods Soldier be he:
Had I as many Sonnes, as I haue haires,
I would not wiſh them to a fairer death:
And ſo his Knell is knoll’d.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Hee’s worth more ſorrow,
And that Ile ſpend for him.

speech.speaker: Sey.
speech.line: He’s worth no more,
They ſay he parted well, and paid his ſcore,
And ſo God be with him. Here comes newer comfort.

speech.speaker: Macd.
speech.line: Haile King, for ſo thou art.
Behold where ſtands
Th’ Vſurpers curſed head: the time is free:
I ſee thee compaſt with thy Kingdomes Pearle,
That ſpeake my ſalutation in their minds:
Whoſe voyces I deſire alowd with mine.
Haile King of Scotland.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Haile King of Scotland.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: We ſhall not ſpend a large expence of time,
Before we reckon with your ſeuerall loues,
And make vs euen with you. My Thanes and Kinſmen
Henceforth be Earles, the firſt that euer Scotland
In ſuch an Honor nam’d: What’s more to do,
Which would be planted newly with the time,
As calling home our exil’d Friends abroad,
That fled the Snares of watchfull Tyranny,
Producing forth the cruell Miniſters
Of this dead Butcher, and his Fiend-like Queene;
Who (as ’tis thought) by ſelfe and violent hands,
Tooke off her life. This, and what needfull elſe
That call’s vpon vs, by the Grace of Grace,
We will performe in meaſure, time, and place:
So thankes to all at once, and to each one,
Whom we inuite, to ſee vs Crown’d at Scone.
